reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s treatment of value-destroying threats in the trade/compromise pathway. That topic is fairly central because sections 3.3–3.4 and parts of the conclusion use threats as a key determinant of whether moral trade yields mostly-great futures or instead wipes out most value; undermining that would noticeably shift the essay’s optimism/pessimism balance about the trade route (though it wouldn’t overturn the broader anti-WAM-convergence case or other blockers). The critique has moderate strength: it successfully points out a methodological gap (authors explicitly say they haven’t dug in) and the lack of modeling between ‘possible’ and ‘EV-dominating,’ but it doesn’t demonstrate that threats are unlikely or that equilibrium forces reliably neutralize them—so it weakens confidence more than it refutes the claims. Most assertions are accurate, with slight overstatement in calling threats “decisive” given the essay’s acknowledged uncertainty. It is clear, focused on a single issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: Threats drive key conclusions but receive insufficient analytical treatment
